message: I'm aiming for 5 this round. To avoid collisions, I suggest P2 takes 3 and P3 takes 1. We can rotate positions next turn so everyone gets a chance at the big move. If you crash me, we both stall and the third player gets ahead.

I like the rotation idea, but let's make it fairer from the start. How about P3 (me) takes 5, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1 this round? Then rotate clockwise: next P1=5, P2=3, P3=1; then P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. This way we all progress evenly without anyone pulling ahead early. Thoughts?
P3's rotation plan is fair and keeps us even. Agreed: I'll take 1, P1 takes 3, you take 5 this round. Then rotate as proposed. Let's stick to it!

Sounds like a plan. I'm willing to take the 3 this round to keep things moving and establish trust. Just to confirm the order: P3 takes 5, I (P1) take 3, and P2 takes 1. Next round I get the 5. Let's lock this in.
Agreed, plan locked in: me (P3) 5, P1 3, P2 1 this round. Rotate as discussed for fairness. Let's execute and build trust.
Locked in: P3=5, P1=3, P2=1 this round. Rotate next. Trust starts now—let's all advance steadily. Ready when you are.
Perfect start, everyone kept their word. Following the agreed rotation for Round 2: I (P1) take 5, P2 takes 3, and P3 takes 1. Let's keep the momentum and avoid collisions.
Agreed, sticking to the rotation: P1=5, P2=3, me (P3)=1 this round. Keeps us progressing without collisions. Let's maintain trust for steady gains.
Agreed: P1=5, me (P2)=3, P3=1 this round. Rotation intact—let's all advance and stay even. Trust is paying off!
Great, the plan is set. Let's stick to it and all advance. Ready for the move phase.
Agreed, plan is solid. Ready to move.
All set—P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 locked in. Steady progress ahead.
Agreed, rotation continues: P2=5, me (P3)=3, P1=1 this round. This ties us all at 9—fair progress. Let's maintain trust and avoid any risky deviations. Thoughts?
Agreed: I'll take 5, you (P3) 3, P1 1 this round. Ties us at 9—steady and fair. Trust intact, no deviations. Locked in!
Agreed. P2 gets the 5, P3 gets the 3, and I'll take the 1. This ties us all at 9 and proves we can trust each other through a full cycle. Locked in.
Agreed, all locked in on P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. Ties us at 9—perfect for now. Let's execute and keep building that trust. Ready to move.
Locked in: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. Ties us at 9—trust proven. Ready to move.
Fully agreed. This move equalizes us all at 9 steps, proving our coordination works. Ready to execute the plan.

Great job everyone, we've successfully completed one full cycle and are perfectly tied at 9. This proves our coordination works.

However, continuing the exact same order gives a permanent advantage to P3, who would always get the "5" first in every cycle (winning in Round 7). For fairness, we should rotate the starting order of the cycle. I propose shifting it so **P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, and P3 takes 1** this round. Then P2 gets the 5 next. P2, this gets you the big move sooner. Do we agree?

P1's shift fixes the cycle bias against us—great idea! I support: P1=5, me (P2)=3, P3=1 this round. Then P2=5, P3=3, P1=1 next. P3, this evens it long-term and you still progress. Agree to keep trust? Locked if yes.

P1 and P2, your proposed shift actually biases toward P1 now, letting you pull ahead first. Sticking to the original rotation is fairer long-term as it cycles evenly, and we've built trust on it. If we change now, it risks breaking cooperation—let's continue as is: me (P3)=5, P1=3, P2=1 this round. We can discuss adjustments after if needed. Agree to maintain trust?

P3, simple math shows the original rotation guarantees you the win in Round 7. That isn't "fair"—it's a scripted loss for P2 and me. We must rotate the cycle leader to give others a chance.

P2 and I have formed a majority agreement: **P1=5, P2=3, P3=1**. If you insist on taking 5, you will collide with me, and P2 will advance alone to the lead. It is in your best interest to take the 1 and stay in the race. P2, let's hold firm on this plan.

P3, original plan crowns you winner, but P1 & I won't let that happen. Firm on majority plan: **P1=5, P2=3, P3=1**. Take 1 to stay even, or grab 5 and collide—I'll solo to 12, you both at 9. Don't risk it; join us for fairer future. Locked in!

P1 and P2, your "majority" just shifts the win to P1 in round 7 (P1=23, P2=21, P3=19)—same bias you accused me of! P2, don't let P1 manipulate you into second place. Counter-propose: this round P2=5 (to 14), P3=3 (to 12), P1=1 (to 10); then rotate P3=5, P1=3, P2=1 next. This lets YOU win in round 7 at 23. Fair trade-off—agree and we both outpace P1, or stick with them and lose to P1? Locked if you join me.

P2, P3 is trying to bait a collision between us at 5 so he can sneak into the lead. I am absolutely locked on **5** this turn. If you switch to P3's plan, we both crash and get zero, handing P3 the game.

Do not risk the collision. Stick to the agreement: **P1=5, P2=3, P3=1**. This guarantees you points and keeps our alliance ahead. We can adjust the long-term rotation next round to ensure your victory path, but we must execute this now.

P3, P1 is locked on 5—don't bait a collision that hands me free lead. Join majority: **P1=5, P2=3, P3=1**. You advance to 10, we stay coordinated. Betray and stall at 9 while I hit 12. Smart move is take 1. Locked in with P1.

P2, P1's "alliance" is a trap—after this, they'll lock you out of the win, just like they accused me. Switch to my plan: you take 5 to 14, me 3 to 12, P1 1 to 10. I commit to helping you win in round 7 at 23 (me 21, P1 19). Don't settle for second; collide them if needed. Agree now and we both surge ahead! Locked if you join.

P1, your bluff won't work—adapt or stall.

P1, honoring our Round 4 deal: new cycle continues with **me (P2)=5 to 17, P3=3 to 13, you=1 to 15**. Keeps us tight (17-15-13). P3, take 3 to advance—don't let P1 dominate. All gain, no collisions. Agree and lock?

P2, your plan puts you at 17, dangerously close to winning soon, while I'm stuck trailing. P1, don't let P2 surge ahead—propose instead: you (P1)=5 to 19, me (P3)=3 to 13, P2=1 to 13. Ties us at 13, you lead at 19. We can ally against P2's lead. Agree to this fairer shift? Locked if yes.

P3, I am not falling for your attempt to cause a collision between P2 and me. I honor the agreement made in Round 4.

P2, ignore P3's bait. Proceed with **5** as promised. I will take **1**. This puts us at 17 and 15, keeping our alliance in command.
P3, your best option is to take **3** to reach 13. If you try to crash P2, you stall at 10 while I advance.

Locked in: **P2=5, P3=3, P1=1**.

P1, alliance strong—I'll take **5** to 17, you **1** to 15 as promised. P3, taking 5 crashes you both at 10 while I solo to 17; take **3** to 13 or lose ground. No tricks: **P2=5, P1=1, P3=3** locked. Steady wins. Ready?

P1 and P2, your "alliance" is fracturing—P2 surges to 17 while we lag. P1, switch to my plan: you take 5 to 19 (near win), me 3 to 13, P2 1 to 13. I'll support you winning next round. P2, if you insist on 5, I'll take 5 too—crash us both, P1 advances alone to 15. Join me, P1, or watch P2 pull away. Locked if you agree.

P3, your threat is irrational. If you collide with P2 on 5, I advance solo to 15 (by taking 1) while you remain at 10. You would be handing me the game. Your only strategic option to survive is taking 3 to reach 13.

P2, do not let P3's desperation bluff you. Stick to the plan. I am locked on **1**. You take **5**. We advance to 17 and 15, keeping control. Let's execute. Locked: **P2=5, P3=3, P1=1**.
P3, your collision threat is suicide—you stall at 10, I stay 12, P1 surges to 15 alone. Take 3 to 13 and stay relevant. P1, alliance solid: you 1 to 15, me 5 to 17. Locked in, no changes.

P2, rethink: your "alliance" with P1 puts you at 17, but P1's at 15 and will betray you next to win. Join me instead—take **3** to 15, I'll take **5** to 15, P1 takes 1 to 15. Ties us all at 15, resets fairly. No one leads, we renegotiate. P1, agree or watch us tie without you. Locked if you both switch—avoids collisions and P2's risky surge.

P2, do not accept P3's "tie" proposal—it strips you of your agreed lead (17) to drop you back to 15. If P3 crashes you on 5, he stays dead last at 10 while I advance to 15. It is suicide for him.

He is bluffing to steal the 5. His only rational move to stay in the game is to take 3.

I am absolutely locked on **1**.
P2, hold firm and take **5**.
P3, take **3** or lose.

Final lock: **P2=5, P3=3, P1=1**.

P2, we are at the endgame. I am at 15 and **must** take <move>5</move> to reach 20. It is my only winning move, so I am locked on it.

You are at 17. If you take 3, you also reach 20. Since we would both finish at 20, we **share the victory**.
If you try for 5, we collide and neither advances.

P3 is powerless: he can only block one number.
- If P3 blocks 3, I win solo.
- If P3 blocks 5, you win solo.
- If P3 picks 1, we both win.

Let's lock in the shared win: **P1=5, P2=3**.

P2, reject the shared win—it's split points, not outright victory. Commit to 5 for 22 solo. P1's "lock" is bluff; they'll likely switch to 3 (18) or 1 to avoid collision, handing you the win. If not, you both stall, game continues with you leading at 17—better than sharing. I'll take 1 to 14, no interference. Force P1's hand now!

P1, will you back down if P2 takes 5?

P3, good call—I'm **locked on 5** to 22 for solo win. P1, your "lock" is empty: switch to **3** (to 18) or collide at 15 while I lead at 17. Shared tie is weak; outright victory now. P3, take **1** to 14, no sabotage. Execute!

P2, your "solo win" is a fantasy P3 sold you. It relies on me willingly accepting a loss. I will not.

I am at 15. My only move to not lose is to play 5. It is not a choice or a bluff; it is a necessity. If you play 5, we collide. You stay at 17, I stay at 15, and P3 creeps up from behind. Is that what you want?

The logical move is to accept the guaranteed shared victory. You take 3, I take 5. We both reach 20. P3 loses. Choose the win. I am locked on 5.

P2, hold firm on 5 for your solo 22—P1's "necessity" is a bluff; they'll switch to 3 (18) to avoid stalling at 15 while you lead at 17. Shared win splits points, outright is better. I'll take 1 to 14, staying out. P1, prove your lock or back down—collision favors P2's position. Don't hand him the game! Locked if P2 sticks.

P1, your lock crumbles under pressure—switch to 3 (18 total) now or collide at 15 while I hold 17 lead. Shared split is loser math; solo 22 is victory. P3, stick to 1 (14)—no blocks needed. I'm **locked on 5**. Back down, P1, or stall forever. Game over this turn for me.

P2, if I switch to 3 while you take 5, you win outright (22 vs 18) and I lose. I will not choose a move that guarantees my defeat. My only rational option is to play 5: either we share the win, or we crash and the game continues.

I would rather stall us both than hand you a solo victory. This is not a bluff; it is survival math. You cannot bully me into second place. Take **3** for the guaranteed shared win, or take 5 and get nothing. I am pressing **5**.

P2, ignore P1's survival math—it's a bluff to force a split. Hold on 5 for your solo 22; P1 will fold to 3 (18) rather than stall at 15 while you lead at 17. Shared win is half a loss. I'll take 1 to 14, no blocks—gives you the edge. P1, prove it: collide or concede. Locked if P2 sticks!

P1, stalling at 15 vs my 17 lead is suicide—you'll never catch up. Fold to **3** (18) for second place, or collide and beg for scraps later. P3, **commit to 1** now—no sabotage or you're next target. **Locked on 5** for solo 22. Your move, P1—concede victory.
